paragraphs.text:
%md
# About
**Lab:** Exploring DataFrames Using the Apache Spark Shell
**Objective:** You will use the Spark shell to work with DataFrames
**File locations:** 
```
/home/devuser/data/telco/devices.json
```

**Successful outcome:** You will be able to successfully use the Spark shell to work with DataFrames.
**Before you begin:** Complete Lab: Working with HDFS
**Related lessons:**  

---

msg.data:
About

Lab: Exploring DataFrames Using the Apache Spark Shell
Objective: You will use the Spark shell to work with DataFrames
File locations:

$DEVDATA/devices.json

Successful outcome: You will be able to successfully use the Spark shell to work with DataFrames.
Before you begin: Complete Lab: Working with HDFS
Related lessons:
Setup

paragraphs.text:
%md
You will start by viewing and bookmarking the Spark documentation in your browser.
Then you will start the Spark shell and read a simple JSON file into a DataFrame.

**Important:** This exercise assumes you are comfortable working with HDFS. You can practice your skills by completing exercise `03 - Working with HDFS`.

msg.data:
You will start by viewing and bookmarking the Spark documentation in your browser.
Then you will start the Spark shell and read a simple JSON file into a DataFrame.

Important: This exercise depends on Hands-On Exercise: Working with HDFS.
*** Does this link work? ***
If you did not complete that exercise, run the course catch-up script and advance to the current exercise:

$ $DEVSH/scripts/catchup.sh
Lab
View the Spark Documentation

paragraphs.title: 1 - Open the Spark Documentation
paragraphs.text:
%md
View the Spark documentation in your web browser by visiting [http://spark.apache.org/docs/2.4.0/](http://spark/apache.org/docs/2.4.0/).

msg.data: View the Spark documentation in your web browser by visiting http://spark.apache.org/docs/2.4.0/.

paragraphs.title: 2 - Review the guide for SQL, DataFrames, and Datasets
paragraphs.text:
%md
From the **Programming Guides** menu, select **SQL, DataFrames, and Datasets**. Briefly review the guide and bookmark the page for later reference.

msg.data: From the Programming Guides menu, select SQL, DataFrames, and Datasets. Briefly review the guide and bookmark the page for later reference.

paragraphs.title: 3 - Review the API documentation
paragraphs.text:
%md
From the API Docs menu, select Python. Bookmark the API page for use during class. Later exercises will refer to this documentation

msg.data:
From the API Docs menu, select either Scala or Python, depending on your
language preference. Bookmark the API page for use during class. Later exercises
will refer to this documentation

paragraphs.title: 4 - Review the SQL module for Python
paragraphs.text:
%md
Locate the `pyspark.sql` module. This module contains most of the classes you will be working with in this course. At the top are some of the key classes in the module. View the API for the DataFrame class; these are the operations you will practice using in this exercise.

msg.data:
If you are viewing the Python API, locate the pyspark.sql module. This module
contains most of the classes you will be working with in this course. At the top are
some of the key classes in the module. View the API for the DataFrame class; these
are the operations you will practice using in this exercise.
Start the Spark Shell

paragraphs.title: 5 - Starting the Spark shell
paragraphs.text:
%md
**Note:** In this environment a Spark shell is started by the `pyspark` interpreter so you do not need to manually start one. In a normal terminal, however, you can start the Spark shell for Python by using the `pyspark` command.

paragraphs.title: 6 - Confirm that a SparkSession has been instantiated
paragraphs.text:
%md
Spark creates a `SparkSession` object for you called `spark`. Make sure the object exists. Use the command below to display information about the spark object such as: `<pyspark.sql.session.SparkSession at` *address*`>`

msg.data:
Spark creates a SparkSession object for you called spark. Make sure the object
exists. Use the first command below if you are using Python, and the second one if
you are using Scala. (You only need to complete the exercises in Python or Scala.)

Python will display information about the spark object such as:
<pyspark.sql.session.SparkSession at address>
Scala will display similar information in a different format:
org.apache.spark.sql.SparkSession = org.apache.spark.sql.SparkSession@address

Note: In subsequent instructions, both Python and Scala commands will be shown
but not noted explicitly; Python shell commands are in blue and preceded with
pyspark>, and Scala shell commands are in red and preceded with scala>.

!!!! Needs an edit, refers to colored commands which don't exist in Zeppelin !!! *
<pyspark.sql.session.SparkSession object at 0x7fd5c9254e90>

paragraphs.title: 7 - View available Spark session methods
paragraphs.text:
%md
Using command completion, you can see all the available Spark session methods: type `spark.` (spark followed by a dot) and then the `TAB` key.

**Note:** To exit the Python Spark shell, press `Ctrl+D` or type `exit`. However, you won't need to terminate the shell in this environment.

msg.data:
Using command completion, you can see all the available Spark session methods:
type spark. (spark followed by a dot) and then the TAB key.

Note: You can exit the Scala shell by typing sys.exit. To exit the Python shell,
press Ctrl+D or type exit. However, stay in the shell for now to complete the
remainder of this exercise.

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Read and Display a JSON File

msg.data: Read and Display a JSON File

paragraphs.title: 8 - Review the data file you will be using
paragraphs.text:
%md
Review the simple text file you will be using: `/home/devuser/data/telco/devices.json`. You can view the file by  in an editor, or by starting a new terminal window then using the `less` command. (Do not modify the file.) This file contains records for each of the supported devices. For example:

```
    {"devnum":1,"release_dt":"2008-10-21T00:00:00.000-07:00", "make":"Sorrento","model":"F00L","dev_type":"phone"}
```

Notice the field names and types of values in the first few records.

msg.data:
Review the simple text file you will be using: $DEVDATA/devices.json. You can
view the file either in the Pluma editor, or by starting a new terminal window then
using the less command. (Do not modify the file.) This file contains records for
each of Loudacre's supported devices. For example:

{"devnum":1,"release_dt":"2008-10-21T00:00:00.000-07:00", "make":"Sorrento","model":"F00L","dev_type":"phone"}

Notice the field names and types of values in the first few records.

paragraphs.title: 9 - Upload the data file to HDFS
paragraphs.text:
%md
Upload the data file to the /user/zeppelin/ directory in HDFS.

msg.data:
Upload the data file to the /devsh_loudacre directory in HDFS:

$ hdfs dfs -put $DEVDATA/devices.json /devsh_loudacre/

Found 7 items
drwx------   - zeppelin hdfs          0 2020-05-21 12:02 /user/zeppelin/.Trash
drwxr-xr-x   - zeppelin hdfs          0 2020-05-21 17:42 /user/zeppelin/.sparkStaging
drwxrwxrwx   - zeppelin hdfs          0 2020-05-21 17:38 /user/zeppelin/conf
-rw-r--r--   3 zeppelin hdfs       5483 2020-05-21 18:32 /user/zeppelin/devices.json
drwxr-xr-x   - zeppelin hdfs          0 2020-05-21 05:55 /user/zeppelin/kb
drwxrwxrwx   - zeppelin hdfs          0 2020-05-21 17:38 /user/zeppelin/notebook
drwxrwxrwx   - zeppelin hdfs          0 2020-04-29 00:53 /user/zeppelin/test

paragraphs.title: 10 - Create a DataFrame based on the devices.json file
paragraphs.text:
%md
In the Spark shell, create a new DataFrame based on the devices.json file in HDFS.

msg.data:
In the Spark shell, create a new DataFrame based on the devices.json file in
HDFS.

paragraphs.title: 11 - View the schema of the DataFrame
paragraphs.text:
%md
Spark has not yet read the data in the file, but it has scanned the file to infer the schema. View the schema, and note that the column names match the record field names in the JSON file.

msg.data:
root
 |-- dev_type: string (nullable = true)
 |-- devnum: long (nullable = true)
 |-- make: string (nullable = true)
 |-- model: string (nullable = true)
 |-- release_dt: string (nullable = true)

paragraphs.title: 12 - Display the data using the show action
paragraphs.text:
%md
Display the data in the DataFrame using the show function. If you don't pass an argument to `show`, Spark will display the first 20 rows in the DataFrame. For this step, display the first five rows. Note that the data is displayed in tabular form, using the column names defined in the schema.

msg.data:
Display the data in the DataFrame using the show function. If you don't pass an
argument to show, Spark will display the first 20 rows in the DataFrame. For this
step, display the first five rows. Note that the data is displayed in tabular form,
using the column names defined in the schema.

Note: Like many Spark queries, this command is the same whether you are using
Scala or Python.

paragraphs.title: 13 - Access the data using the take action
paragraphs.text:
%md
The `show` and `printSchema` operations are actions--that is, they return a value from the distributed DataFrame to the Spark driver. Both functions display the data in a nicely formatted table. These functions are intended for interactive use in the shell, but do not allow you actually work with the data that is returned. Try using the `take` action instead, which returns a list of Row objects. You can display the data by iterating through the collection.

msg.data:
The show and printSchema operations are actions–that is, they return a value
from the distributed DataFrame to the Spark driver. Both functions display the data
in a nicely formatted table. These functions are intended for interactive use in the
shell, but do not allow you actually work with the data that is returned. Try using
the take action instead, which returns an array (Scala) or list (Python) of Row
objects. You can display the data by iterating through the collection.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
rows = devDF.take(5)
for row in rows: print row

msg.data:
Row(dev_type=u'phone', devnum=1, make=u'Sorrento', model=u'F00L', release_dt=u'2008-10-21T00:00:00.000-07:00')
Row(dev_type=u'phone', devnum=2, make=u'Titanic', model=u'2100', release_dt=u'2010-04-19T00:00:00.000-07:00')
Row(dev_type=u'phone', devnum=3, make=u'MeeToo', model=u'3.0', release_dt=u'2011-02-18T00:00:00.000-08:00')
Row(dev_type=u'phone', devnum=4, make=u'MeeToo', model=u'3.1', release_dt=u'2011-09-21T00:00:00.000-07:00')
Row(dev_type=u'phone', devnum=5, make=u'iFruit', model=u'1', release_dt=u'2008-10-21T00:00:00.000-07:00')
Query a DataFrame

paragraphs.title: 14 - Count the number of items in the DataFrame
paragraphs.text:
%md
Use the `count` action to return the number of items in the DataFrame.

msg.data: Use the count action to return the number of items in the DataFrame.

paragraphs.title: 15 - Use the select transformation
paragraphs.text:
%md
DataFrame transformations typically return another DataFrame. Try using a `select` transformation to return a DataFrame with only the `make` and `model` columns, then display its schema. Note that only the selected columns are in the schema.

msg.data:
DataFrame transformations typically return another DataFrame. Try using a
select transformation to return a DataFrame with only the make and model
columns, then display its schema. Note that only the selected columns are in the
schema.

pyspark> makeModelDF = devDF.select("make","model")
pyspark> makeModelDF.printSchema()

scala> val makeModelDF = devDF.select("make","model")
scala> makeModelDF.printSchema

paragraphs.title: 16 - Execute the query by calling an action operation
paragraphs.text:
%md
A query is a series of one or more transformations followed by an action. Spark does not execute the query until you call the action operation. Display the first 20 lines of the final DataFrame in the series using the `show` action.

msg.data:
A query is a series of one or more transformations followed by an action. Spark
does not execute the query until you call the action operation. Display the first 20
lines of the final DataFrame in the series using the show action.

paragraphs.title: 17 - Chain multiple transformations in a single command
paragraphs.text:
%md
Transformations in a query can be chained together. Execute a single command to show the results of a query using select and where. The resulting DataFrame will contain only the columns `devnum`, `make`, and `model`, and only the rows where the make is `Ronin`.

msg.data:
Transformations in a query can be chained together. Execute a single command to
show the results of a query using select and where. The resulting DataFrame will
contain only the columns devnum, make, and model, and only the rows where the
make is Ronin.

+------+-----+--------------+
|devnum| make|         model|
+------+-----+--------------+
|    15|Ronin|Novelty Note 1|
|    17|Ronin|Novelty Note 3|
|    18|Ronin|Novelty Note 2|
|    19|Ronin|Novelty Note 4|
|    46|Ronin|            S4|
|    47|Ronin|            S1|
|    48|Ronin|            S3|
|    49|Ronin|            S2|
+------+-----+--------------+

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Result
**You have now:** You have now successfully used the Spark shell to work with DataFrames.

---

paragraphs.text:
%md
We hope you've enjoyed this lab. Below are additional resources that you should find useful:

1. [Hortonworks Apache Spark Tutorials](http://hortonworks.com/tutorials/#tuts-developers) are your natural next step where you can explore Spark in more depth.
2. [Hortonworks Community Connection (HCC)](https://community.hortonworks.com/spaces/85/data-science.html?type=question) is a great resource for questions and answers on Spark, Data Analytics/Science, and many more Big Data topics.
3. [Hortonworks Apache Spark Docs](https://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP3/HDP-3.0.1/spark-overview/content/analyzing_data_with_apache_spark.html) - official Spark documentation.
4. [Hortonworks Apache Zeppelin Docs](https://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP3/HDP-3.0.1/zeppelin-overview/content/overview.html) - official Zeppelin documentation.

msg.data:
We hope you've enjoyed this lab. Below are additional resources that you should find useful:

  1. Hortonworks Apache Spark Tutorials are your natural next step where you can explore Spark in more depth.
  2. Hortonworks Community Connection (HCC) is a great resource for questions and answers on Spark, Data Analytics/Science, and many more Big Data topics.
  3. Hortonworks Apache Spark Docs - official Spark documentation.
  4. Hortonworks Apache Zeppelin Docs - official Zeppelin documentation.
